entries.title: Across the US, deadly winter storms leave 1.4 million homes in the dark
entries.description: Some 240 million Americans, 70 percent of the population, were under weather warnings, as wind chills brought temperatures down as low as -48 Celsius.

entries.title: What we know about the Paris shooter
entries.description: The suspect had been released from custody on December 12 pending trial over a recent migrant tent attack, according to the Paris prosecutor's office.

entries.title: US Congress greenlights $1.7 trillion spending bill with Ukraine aid
entries.description: Lawmakers provided roughly $45 billion for Ukraine and NATO allies, more than even US President Joe Biden requested, an acknowledgment that future rounds of funding are not guaranteed with a new GOP-led House.

entries.title: For France, Iran's regime remains impenetrable
entries.description: Held at a distance by an erratic visa policy, French diplomats have faced difficulty in understanding the Iranian regime, which is often dubbed a 'black box' due to its impenetrable nature.

entries.title: 'Glass Onion': A game of massacre among the ultra-rich
entries.description: Daniel Craig reprises his character of a perceptive investigator, first created in 'Knives Out', while surrounded by stars playing themselves.

entries.title: 'Qatargate' threatens to derail EU-Gulf relations
entries.description: Since the corruption case emerged, EU member states have done everything they can to avoid targeting the emirate in official speeches. But the scandal is freezing the bloc's ambitions in the Gulf.

entries.title: French rugby boss Laporte gives up all prerogatives to keep title
entries.description: After meeting with the sports minister, the head of the French Rugby Federation, who was found guilty of favoritism, accepted to step back from his responsibilities.

entries.title: DR Congo's M23 rebels retreat from occupied territory in Kibumba
entries.description: The rebels left the strategic Kibumba area near Goma, eastern Congo's regional capital,  in line with an agreement made last month at a summit in Angola.

entries.title: Pakistan's former PM Imran Khan edges country toward destablization
entries.description: The former leader is continuing with his power struggle against the government, calling for early elections. The country is in the grip of an economic crisis and under repeated attacks by the Taliban.

entries.title: 'Qatargate': EU scandal weakens Italy's already-struggling Democratic Party
entries.description: The central role of a former member of Italy's Democratic Party is drawing negative attention to a party that was already facing political difficulty.

entries.title: World Cup winner Blaise Matuidi retires
entries.description: The midfielder was omitted from Inter Miami's squad for this season.

entries.title: Marine Le Pen tries to dissociate herself from violent far-right groups
entries.description: In a letter to the prime minister, the far-right leader asked for the government to dissolve extremist groups 'regardless of their political profile.'

entries.title: Prosecutor clears Spanish forces over Melilla deaths
entries.description: At least 23 African migrants died in June, trying to reach the Spanish enclave.

entries.title: Mike Hodges, British director behind 'Get Carter', dies aged 90
entries.description: In 1971, the filmmaker left a lasting mark with his first film, 'Get Carter' but never really equaled this masterpiece. He died on December 17 at the age of 90.

entries.title: French rail ticket inspectors embark on Christmas strike
entries.description: The national rail company found an agreement with unions to avoid a New Year's strike. But the Christmas strike was orchestrated by ticket inspectors independently of unions.

entries.title: Shooting in Paris leaves two dead, four injured
entries.description: Officials said the shooter, a man in his 60s, had been arrested.

entries.title: French rail strike: Unions lift planned New Year strike
entries.description: An agreement was found between management and unions to avoid a New Year's strike. But Christmas strikes are underway, with one in three trains canceled on Friday, December 23.

entries.title: Striking UK airport passport control staff leave passengers facing delays
entries.description: Around 1,000 workers at six UK airports are taking part in the stoppage on Friday, December 23 − the first of eight planned until January 1.

entries.title: AI video surveillance will make French debut at 2024 Paris Olympics
entries.description: The government's bill to prepare for the Paris 2024 Olympic Games plans to allow for artificial intelligence to be used in video surveillance for a 'temporary' period of time.

entries.title: Macron calls for solving Lebanon's problems and 'getting rid of those who don't know how to'
entries.description: The French president called on new leadership in Lebanon, and mentioned the possibility of a regional conference similar to the one he just co-chaired on Iraq.

entries.title: World Cup: French sports minister calls Argentina 'inelegant winners'
entries.description: The president of the French Football Federation also wrote to his Argentine counterpart to complain about the team's celebrations.

entries.title: Donald Trump's week of setbacks
entries.description: From the investigation into the assault on the Capitol last year to an incriminating tax audit, the former US president is plagued by scandal, with little support from the Republican Party.

entries.title: Macron urges Lebanon to 'get rid' of leaders blocking reforms
entries.description: Speaking to a Lebanese newspaper, the French president called for new leadership in the country whose economy is collapsing.

entries.title: French rail strikes: Why a TGV can't run without a ticket inspector
entries.description: Ticket inspectors are set to go on strike on Christmas weekend. But contrary to their job title, they don't just check tickets. They have several responsibilities that make them essential.

entries.title: Georgia court to rule over fate of former president Saakashvili
entries.description: Judges are to decide whether the former president, who has been imprisoned since his return to Georgia in 2021, should be released or have his sentence postponed on health grounds. Findings of a medical report established he was 'poisoned.'

entries.title: Christmas train strikes: French government considers reforming minimum service
entries.description: A strike by train ticket inspectors means that two out of five trains risk being canceled on the week-end of Christmas.

entries.title: 'Qatargate': Investigation reveals simple corruption scheme
entries.description: Greek MEP Eva Kaili is still detained after a hearing on Thursday.

entries.title: Who has to work in France during the holiday season?
entries.description: According to numbers from the Ministry of Labor, only one in two employees is off during the Winter break. Firefighters, restaurant owners, bus drivers... Some jobs don't stop.

entries.title: 'Qatargate': How members of the European Parliament voted on Qatar
entries.description: As suspicion turns inwards, members of the European Parliament are wondering to what extent Qatar managed to influence voting choices. 'Le Monde' analyses their record.

entries.title: No World Cup trophy for Argentina's presidential palace
entries.description: The political truce that was hoped for after Lionel Messi's team's World Cup victory was short-lived.

entries.title: In 845-page report, January 6 committee describes Trump's 'multi-part conspiracy'
entries.description: The former president actively tried to overturn the lawful results of the 2020 presidential election and failed to act to stop his supporters from attacking the Capitol, details the report concluding an 18-month investigation.

entries.title: Diplomatic tensions between DRC and Rwanda reaches new heights after Kishishe tragedy
entries.description: Several Western governemnts, including Paris, Brussels and Berlin, have condemned Kigali's support for the March 23 Movement rebels.

entries.title: Afghan women no longer allowed to attend university
entries.description: On December 20, Taliban government has 'immediately' and 'until further notice' banned institutions from accepting female students.

entries.title: FTX founder Bankman-Fried allowed $250M bond, house arrest
entries.description: Cryptocurrency entrepreneur will await trial at his parents' California home. He's been charged with fraud for swindling investors and looting customer deposits on his FTX trading platform.
